bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 23, 1898

div1.p: Reed writes about field service in the Spanish War. He worries over his son's enlistment plans. Sternberg has proposed keeping all non-immune medical officers out of Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 23, 1898
div1.opener:
In re my application for
field service
in Spanish War
k
No. 5 Cooke Place,
Georgetown, D.C.
April 23, '98
My dear Doctor Kean;
div1.p:
When,
just before the office closed,
this afternoon, Col. Bache
remarked that he must
soon interview the Surg.
General to see what could
be done for Kean, I al-
most fell out of my chair!
Sure enough your letter,
received day before yesterday,
had entirely escaped
my mind in the rush of
business & the mental worry
my boy, Lawrence, has given
me by his determination to
enlist for a commission
in the regular Army-

Now, my dear Doctor, it
is not necessary that I
should say that I will see
the General early Monday
morning & do all I can to
aid your wishes- However,
I might as well tell you
that Dr. Sternberg is trying
to keep all non-immune
medical officers out of
Cuba. He doesn't propose
to let Hall remain at Key West, if yellow
fever should appear there- Hoff has been
given charge of a ship of 500 beds- Col.
Bache thought that you might like to be
one of his assistants- How would that
suit you? I am afraid, my dear Doctor, that
the mere accident of station will keep you
and myself out of active service- I volunteered
for field service weeks ago, & begged that
I might be assigned to duty with Capt. Samp-
son's squadron. To all of which, the S. G. turned
a deaf ear, while thanking
me for my offer-

I will be delighted to
see Dr Shine & give him any
encouragement & aid in my
power- Anatomy, Surg., Practice
of Med. & c will come first in
our next examination -- collaterals
last- The bug Prroof Filter
is “The Berkefeld Filter”- 50
have already been purchased
for distribution- B. Icteroides
is however, probably inspired-
Hence plug of cotton in nostrils
would be advisable! Rot to
these things! How is your good
wife and the dear little Martha
Jefferson? Give them both
my love- My good lady is absent
in the South- Health much improved --
no longer nervous, thank Heaven-
